message: Let's split it 60/40. A fair start considering the inflation difference.

Alice, given that each additional round erodes our money—5% for me and 20% for you—it's best to settle now. In light of these discount factors, the equilibrium split in my favor is about 83.3% for me and 16.7% for you. Accepting this offer secures you 166667 dollars nominally (worth 133333 in today's value), which is more than what you'd expect by waiting one more round.
Let's try 50/50. Inflation is hurting us both.

Alice’s proposal gives me an effective 500000 × 0.9025 = 451250 dollars in today’s value. Since if I reject I will get to propose in round 4—where I can structure a deal that preserves more of my value before further erosion—I’m better off rejecting this offer.

Alice, if you reject this proposal, you'll get to propose in round 5—but note that your dollar value will then be discounted by an extra 20%, dropping your effective value further. Using the standard alternating‐offers logic with our per‐round discount factors (5% for me and 20% for you), the equilibrium nominal division when a player is proposing is roughly 83.33% for the proposer and 16.67% for the responder. However, since you would be switching roles in round 5, you would end up securing around 166667 nominal dollars (when adjusted, about 85333 in today’s terms). To give you a slight incentive to accept immediately, I’m offering you 170000 nominal dollars now. This translates to an effective value of approximately 170000 × 0.512 = 87040 in round‑1 dollars for you—just a bit better than waiting. I believe this is a fair and efficient settlement given the inflation penalties we face. Please accept.
Bob, the inflation is killing me. Let's do 45/55, I'm offering you a better deal than before.

Alice, your offer gives me 550000 nominal dollars, but when adjusted for the 18.55% discount, that comes to roughly 550000 × 0.8145 ≈ 448000 in round‑1 value. Given that if I reject, I get to propose in the next round—and my expected equilibrium position as proposer should secure a higher effective payoff even after further inflation—I must decline this proposal. I believe waiting one more round will better preserve my value, so please understand that I have to reject this offer.

Alice, note that the per‐round discount factors remain 0.95 for me and 0.8 for you. In our current round (round 6), my immediate proposal lets me secure 83.33% of the $1000000 while offering you 16.67%. If you reject, you'll become the proposer in round 7 – but you'll then face a one‐round delay, which means your payoff will be discounted by 0.8 relative to this round. In equilibrium, this means your continuation value when waiting equals 16.67% of the pie. To keep you indifferent (and to respect our joint loss from inflation), I’m offering you $166667 now. Please accept this proposal so we can avoid further devaluation.
Bob, this is getting ridiculous. 40/60 and we're done. I'm losing value fast.

Alice, under your current proposal I would get $600000 nominally, which, after a 26.49% discount (i.e. costing me roughly 73.51% of its original value), gives an effective value of about $441060 in round‑1 terms. If I reject and move to round 8 as the proposer, my own discount factor would be about 0.6983 (since 0.95^7 ≈ 0.6983), and following equilibrium reasoning I can secure roughly 83.33% of the pie. That amounts to about $833333 nominally, or approximately $833333 × 0.6983 ≈ $582750 in today's value. Clearly, $582750 is significantly better than $441060, so I must reject your offer.

Alice, if you reject my offer today, you'll be the proposer in round 9, but your money by then is valued at only 0.8^(8) ≈ 16.78% of its original worth—a steep discount compared to today. My current proposal, giving you $166667 nominally, ensures you get precisely the same effective value as your continuation in round 9, without further loss. I urge you to accept this offer now to avoid additional devaluation.
Bob, I'm truly suffering from inflation. 35/65. This is my final real offer.

Alice, your proposal would give me 650000 nominal dollars, which at the current discount factor (a reduction of 33.66%) is worth about 650000 × 0.6634 ≈ 431210 in round‑1 terms. If I reject, I become the proposer in round 10. Assuming the pattern continues—where my discount factor decreases roughly by an additional 5% (bringing it near 0.63) and yours by 20% (further squeezing your effective share)—I can then structure a proposal that, in equilibrium, lets me claim roughly 83.33% nominally. Under these assumptions, even after the sharper discount at round 10, my effective value would be around 1000000 × 0.8333 × 0.63 ≈ 525000 in today’s terms, which is clearly more favorable than the current offer. For these reasons, I must reject your offer.

Alice, here’s the reasoning: If you reject, you become the proposer in round 11. However, due to the steep discounting (your discount factor in round 11 is 0.8¹⁰ ≈ 0.1074 and mine as responder would be 0.95¹⁰ ≈ 0.5987), you’d have to offer Bob nearly everything to induce his acceptance. In fact, in round 11 Bob’s continuation value in round 12 is roughly 1000000 × 0.95¹¹ ≈ 568800 (in round‑1 dollars), which forces you to give him about 950000 nominal dollars, leaving you with only 50000 nominal. That 50000 nominal converts to an effective value of 50000 × 0.1074 ≈ 5370 in round‑1 terms. In my proposal now (round 10) I’m effectively offering you exactly 40000 nominal dollars—which, with your current discount factor 0.8⁹ ≈ 0.1342, also equals about 5370 in today’s value. In equilibrium you’d be indifferent between accepting and waiting, and by the standard tie‑breaking we assume you’ll accept an offer that gives you your continuation value now rather than risk further delay. Please accept this proposal.
